awd_titl_txt: Panel Study on Transparency and Reproducibility for NCSES Statistics and a Workshop on the Implications of Convergence for Measuring the S&E Workforce and the S&E Enterprise
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics (NCSES) is the nation's leading provider of statistical data on U.S. Science & Engineering (S&E), including data on research and development, the S&E workforce, the condition and progress of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education, and U.S. competitiveness in these areas. NCSES conducts a large number of surveys to measure these characteristics; however, social and technological changes, such as declining survey response rates, constrained budget and staff resources, and alternative sources of data from non-government sources, are making surveys more expensive to conduct and less useful. The Committee on National Statistics (CNSTAT) of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine will conduct two projects for NCSES to improve the relevance and usefulness of its statistical programs and help it address a changing world.  

The first project is focused on better measurement of scientific work.  Because many of the most pressing questions confronting science and society today -- in fields ranging from cell research and nanotechnology to environmental studies and beyond -- are large and complex problems which are inherently interdisciplinary in character, they require collaborative research using multiple methods and approaches from different disciplines. This has been referred to as convergent research, and it is vital that NCSES be able to accurately measure convergent research to inform science policy about the patterns of this research and how it links to scientific advances.  However, measurement of this work is difficult because there is no single accepted definition. To assist NCSES in being able to gather useful data on the extent of convergence in scientific training and research, CNSTAT will convene a workshop to identify and discuss issues in measuring convergence and its implications for the science and engineering (S&E) workforce and the S&E enterprise more broadly. 

The second project is focused on expanding the kinds of data NCSES uses for its statistical program, to potentially incorporate the use of administrative records and other data sets to produce statistics that are relevant, timely, and of high quality for the science policy and research communities. However, using these data sources requires transparency in the sources, quality of data, and methods used so users are able to assess whether the statistics produced are fit for their intended purposes, and for comparison with results from other agencies and countries. In June, 2017, NSF supported a CNSTAT workshop that examined various aspects of transparency and reproducibility of data products from federal statistical agencies, and it was clear that the current approaches to transparency and reproducibility could be improved.  Presentations from other countries highlighted the development of a variety of tools, which could be useful for achieving greater transparency and supporting greater use and reuse of statistical data in the United States. CNSTAT will conduct a consensus study that will provide a thorough assessment of these tools and potential benefits to NCSES, and provide recommendations on developing standards for transparency and reproducibility of NCSES statistics to help data users and maximize the public benefits from NCSES statistical data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics (NCSES) is the nation's leading provider of statistical data on U.S. Science & Engineering (S&E), including data on research and development, the S&E workforce, the condition and progress of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education, and U.S. competitiveness in these areas. The Committee on National Statistics (CNSTAT) of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine conducted two studies at the request of NCSES to assist it in carrying out its core activities and inform decisions for its major data collection programs.

The first study was focused on better measurement of scientific work.  Because many of the most pressing questions confronting science and society today are large and complex problems which are inherently interdisciplinary in character, they require collaborative research using multiple methods and approaches from different disciplines. This has been referred to as convergent research.  CNSTAT convened a workshop in October 2020 to help NCSES set an agenda to inform its methodological research and better measure and assess the implications of convergence for the S&E workforce and enterprise. The workshop brought together scientists and researchers from multiple disciplines, along with experts in science policy, university administration, and other stakeholders to discuss topics such as conceptualizing convergence, how it is practiced, the outcomes and impacts of convergence, efforts at measurement, the feasibility of a national measure of convergence, and an overview of NCSES efforts to date. Workshop participants described the multidimensional nature of convergence and noted numerous challenges and concerns about measuring it in a national survey, including survey respondents? understanding of interdisciplinary research. A proceedings of the workshop is available to download at https://www.nap.edu/catalog/26040/measuring-convergence-in-science-and-engineering-proceedings-of-a-workshop, and the slides and video of the workshop are available at https://www.nationalacademies.org/event/10-22-2020/a-workshop-on-the-implications-of-convergence-for-how-the-national-center-for-science-and-engineering-statistics-measures-the-science-and-engineering-workforce. 

The second study is focused on the transparency of statistics produced by NCSES and other federal statistical agencies. Official statistics are often the result of complex data collection, processing, and estimation methods. The goal of transparency is to enable consumers of federal statistics to understand and evaluate how estimates are generated so users are able to assess whether the statistics produced are fit for their intended purposes, and for comparison with results from other agencies and countries. CNSTAT convened a multidisciplinary consensus panel that examined NCSES? statistical programs and the degree to which the information currently provided by NCSES and the other federal statistical agencies is consistent with the goals of being transparent. The panel produced a report with conclusions and recommendations on developing standards for transparency and reproducibility of NCSES statistics to help data users and maximize the public benefits from its statistical data, which is available at https://www.nap.edu/catalog/26360/transparency-in-statistical-information-for-the-national-center-for-science-and-engineering-statistics-and-all-federal-statistical-agencies.

The panel recommended that NCSES ensure that the contractors that collect or process data for them provide sufficient information to meet NCSES needs for transparency, and that NCSES have more interaction with its data users. The panel?s report also discusses how NCSES could work with other federal statistical agencies to make transparency of processes and methods a high priority and to facilitate the adoption of currently available documentation and archiving standards and tools. The panel identified best practices that all federal statistical agencies can use to determine the extent to which their policies are consistent with transparency, and recommended that agencies pilot and explore existing metadata tools and standards and adopt modern information technology tools to assist in collaborative software development and documentation of workshop and methodology. The panel acknowledges that additional resources will be needed to fully implement their recommendations. 

The intellectual merit these studies includes bringing together leading scientists from a variety of perspectives and disciplines to identify and improve the transparency of NCSES statistics and improving the measurement of the S&E workforce and S&E activities in an evolving environment with changes taking place due to convergence. These studies identify priorities and inform a research agenda for NCSES and provide recommendations for improvements to their statistical programs. 

These studies have broader societal impact in direct and indirect ways. NCSES implementing the recommendations from the transparency study will assist users to better understand and apply NCSES data. The issues raised in the convergence workshop can help NCSES?s prioritize further research to take account of convergence in its statistical programs.  Indirect impacts include improving national statistics and the usability of data sets for basic and applied social, behavioral, and economic sciences research; facilitating interactions between statisticians and scientists in universities and government; and improving the practices of not only NCSES, but also other federal statistical agencies and other large-scale social, behavioral, and economic sciences surveys and research.
